div1.head: Letter from Martha P. Houston to Charlotte C. Sweitzer, January 18, 1902
div1.p:
Your letter
has just reached me. I am so glad
to hear from you. And it is always
such a comfort to know you have
been to see my dear little daughter.
If a longer time than usual has
passed since I wrote it is simply
because I do not remember just
when I do send a letter to you
and the saysame way with Nell.
Little Houston was speaking of
you this morning, so I said what
shall I say to Baltimore ganny.
“I send my love and tell her
what Kris brought to me” he
(2)
answered- He still claims his
toys, and the other day as little
Peggy went to his Chair. He walked
over to her and said. “Ba ba what
did I tell you about that chair”?
This morning he asked me if the
heat was turned on? little Peggy
is learning new words every day
she does look so cute running around,
she shuts all the doors- Mabel was
so glad to know you were making
her a sweater -- she has sleeps in
one every night, and always wears
them inside her dress this Winter.
We have a furnace fire -- which heats
Mabel -- room nicely. We have
moved the Piano into this front
room. The back parlor makes such
a very pleasant setting room for
us, but the front room does not
look as well.

My son is still with me, he has
(3)
been on a visit to the Modesto Ranch.
He said the grain would be all right
for two weeks yet as they had been
having fogs for six weeks in this
country -- but just think we have
had no rain to speak of since
you went away!-

Last Monday we spent the evening
at the Murrays. I am ashamed to
say it is the first time we have
been there since your departure.
We enjoyed seeing them very much.
Did we neglect to mention the about
this damask you sent? We were so
glad to get it and thank you
very much- I have just got the
dining room rug from the cleaners
and andam pleased to see it looking
so bright and clean. They have
brought out the original color.
I have my old friend Tom of whom
you heard me speak so often
this man who said “I should not
worship a graven image” to clean
for me, he does so much better
than the Japs- Yesterday we
gave the parlor a good cleaning.
I worked till nearly four. Then
went to make two calls in the
neighborhood-

That reminds me to say. Mabel &
I went to call on an artist friend
Mrs Richardson- And I thought
while then if you should come to Las
our city again? I should at once
propose our going to see Mrs R.
You can not imagine what a
magnificent view one has from
her house of all the Bay, the
Golden Gate -- and the whole
city- He house is so beautiful
in its simplicity -- it is so
restful and beautiful-

I was very sorry to hear Thomas was
not well, but have quite recovered
by this time?

I did not renew my subscription
in time to get the “Mu; in Art”
yet. I believe I wrote you about
my Christmas books. I love “The
Child of Nature” have read it
twice. It is all true poetry in prose-
Then my other books. “The World
Beautiful” by Lilian Whiting- I think
you would be interested to read
the first and second series-
I pick up this book every day
and find it very helpful-,
How did you enjoy “this right
of way”?- We thought it delightful-
I wonder if you have reserved
my the Transcripts (Boston) There is
such a beautiful article in it on
Jesse in life and work. We have
just received a number of copies
which Walter sent us by request.

Miss Mitchell sent the most
beautiful lace (Namiton) for the
baby I have ever seen. Mabel thinks
she will keep it till Peggy is older-
Please remember me to Mrs Seth.
With love and best wishes.
div1.closer:
Martha P Houston.
P.S. Will send. “Boston Transcript”
to day-
